nodes.text:
A caged window marked SCHEDULING faces the corridor like a confession booth with forms. (pause)
A “NO-SHOW RECOVERY” bin sits under the counter, sealed with a strip of tape, re-taped. (pause)
A board of approved stamp substitutions hangs slightly crooked. (pause)
A press labeled SLOT TOKEN—AUTHORIZED IMPRESSIONS ONLY is bolted to the laminate.

choices.text: ask: I need an interconnection slot.
ask: What are you calling an asset?
show: I'm on an AMR. Issued.
ask: Show me the rule. The one that says I can’t request.
bargain: I have a fiscal cutoff. I need priority.
threaten: If I don’t get a slot, the site doesn’t close. That’s on your desk.
persuade: I’m not asking for a favor. I’m trying to do this clean.
show: Cite OLEA standing and request escalation.
ask: So I don’t ask. I claim an asset.
leave: Step away from the counter.

nodes.text:
Don’t come up here asking for a slot. (pause)
Bring me an asset you already hold. (pause)
If it’s real the slot’s already attached. (pause)
You say “slot” I have to log “denied.” (pause)
Then it’s a whole story in the minutes. (pause)
I’m not doing stories through a cage.
The clerk’s pen is already poised, as if denial is a checkbox they practice.

Time. (pause)
Lane. Tolerance band. Expiry. The whole bundle. (pause)
Everybody calls expiry “flexible”… (pause)
right up until audit week. (pause)
Here? I’m custody. (pause)
That’s what I can put in the log.

Call it whatever. (pause)
People “request” services. (pause)
What I touch here has to be defendable. (pause)
I get stuck with it when review hits.

AMR checks out. Standing. (pause)
Still no slot. (pause)
You slide an AMR at me. (pause)
You’re pushing me to sign identity into property. (pause)
That’s discretion. (pause)
My name ends up on it.

It just means you’re holding an asset. (pause)
The file says “custody.” (pause)
I’m not labeling you. (pause)
That’s the bucket it goes in.

The rule doesn’t care if you ask. (pause)
It won’t let me treat requests as claims. (pause)
People shove the page at me anyway. (pause)
I only write: claims and transfers and recoveries.
The clerk taps the glass twice, as if the rule is physically stored in it.

I can’t write “priority” from this window. (pause)
You say it. It becomes a complaint anyway. (pause)
With an asset, you defend it upchain. (pause)
Without one this counter can’t add weight.
The clerk’s voice stays level; their knuckles whiten on the pen.

Don’t shove that onto my desk. (pause)
If the site stays open it lands here. (pause)
I’m holding claims. That’s it. (pause)
You start assigning outcomes through the cage— (pause)
it reads like coercion in the minutes.

“Clean” doesn’t tell me what to stamp. (pause)
I hear “clean” and wait for “can you—”. (pause)
Run it through the custody chain. (pause)
Make it something that survives review. (pause)
That’s my lane.

Standing. Noted. (pause)
Still nothing on the tray. (pause)
If I send upstairs, it tags me discretionary. (pause)
Then it’s precedent. (pause)
Bring a claim. (pause)
Transfer. (pause)
Recovery. (pause)
Then I can log it clean.

Declarations don’t move anything here. (pause)
Show standing in-chain. (pause)
Otherwise I can’t route it up. (pause)
Put a claimable asset on the counter. (pause)
Or don’t.

Yeah. (pause)
Claim it. On the tray. I record. (pause)
If it holds up it moves. (pause)
If it doesn’t it dies at the glass. (pause)
That’s why I’m back here.
The rule sets: time slots aren’t granted here. They’re taken, transferred, or recovered—defended as property.
